p.seg: Imperial decree reply.
Once one attains non-form, all existences are completely forgotten.
Further inquiry.
Yī dé wú xiàng, wàng wàn yǒu zhě.
may also attain an empty mind to exhaustively explore that true realm;
one should not gradually perceive it.
Imperial decree reply.
The Tathāgata's comprehension of stillness is naturally an exhaustive exploration of truth.
Saints of shallow practice invariably perceive it gradually.
Further inquiry.
If one sees truth as something to be gradually perceived, one cannot suddenly comprehend it.
One should also gradually forget all existences, which cannot be suddenly forgotten.
Imperial decree reply.
Because understandings have superior and inferior levels, there is gradual perception.
Because forgetting the mind has no bias, all existences are simultaneously stilled.
Imperial decree explaining the meaning of Dharmakāya.
Dharmakāya is empty and still.
It is far from the realm of being and non-being.
It is uniquely liberated beyond cause and effect.
It cannot be known by wisdom.
It cannot be recognized by consciousness.
How can it be argued about by appellations?
Intending to reveal the principle, silence is not permissible.
Therefore, we follow speech.
Thus, there is the appellation Dharmakāya.
In India, it is called Dharmaśarīra.
In this land (China), it is called Dharmakāya.
If according to its very essence, it is the designation of self-nature.
If according to speech, then it is a relatively established name.
"Dharma" signifies norm or principle.
"Kāya" has the meaning of possessing substance.
The substance of norm is why it is called Dharmakāya.
Briefly adhering to speech, we roughly present its substance.
It is the permanent body.
What the sage sees is seeing non-movement.
What the ordinary person sees is seeing movement.
Since movement and non-movement are different,
I foolishly believe they cannot be one.
The imperial edict answers:
It is not said that movement and non-movement are each a separate entity.
It precisely states that ordinary people, within non-movement, perversely see this movement.
If discussed in this way, they can be made one.
Again, I inquire:
The substance of true stillness is originally non-moving.
Ordinary people see movement but do not depart from the true substance.
In that case, there is only one truth, and the two truths are not established.
The imperial edict answers:
Substance is constantly interconnected; principle cannot be different.
But ordinary people see the floating and illusory, while sages perceive true stillness.
In terms of the ordinary and the sage, the name of the two truths can be established.
Huì Yǎn of Zhāotí Monastery inquires:
Ordinary people see the mundane, taking arising (birth) as the substance.
Sages see the truth, taking non-arising as the substance.
Not yet understanding arising and non-arising.
Only seeing their difference, by what meaning can one discern their unity?
The imperial decree answers:
Ordinary people create existence from nothing.
Sages discern nothingness from existence.
Existence and non-existence interpenetrate; this is what we speak of as oneness.
Again, I ask:
Not yet understanding that this attains the speaking of oneness.
What is this "one" called?
The imperial decree answers:
Precisely because existence is not different from non-existence, and non-existence is not different from existence.
Therefore, it is named "one," and there is no other name.
Again, I ask:
If non-existence is not different from existence.
And existence is not different from non-existence.
Only seeing their oneness.
How does one establish duality?
The imperial decree answers:
Ordinary people see existence, sages see non-existence.
These two views being distinct, on this basis, duality is formed.
Again, I ask:
Sages seeing non-existence, nothing can be said to be true.
Ordinary people seeing existence, how can it be called true?
The imperial decree answers:
Sages seeing non-existence, in the sage it is true.
Ordinary people firmly believe in existence.
Therefore, concerning all that are considered truths.
Tánzōng 曇宗 of Qīxuán Sì 棲玄寺 inquired,
"Do sages see mundane truths (shìdì 世諦) or not?"
The imperial edict (lìngzhǐ 令旨) replied,
"Sages know that ordinary people see the existence of mundane truths.
If we are speaking of sages, they no longer see this."
Again he inquired,
"Since sages do not see mundane truths,
how do they use mundane truths to teach and transform sentient beings?"
The imperial edict replied,
"Sages, being without delusion, do not see mundane truths.
This does not prevent sages from knowing what ordinary people see.
Therefore, they flexibly adapt to the sentiments of beings and speak of the existence of two truths (èrdì 二諦)."
Again he inquired,
"Sages know that ordinary people see mundane truths.
Is this ordinary person just this?"
The imperial edict replied,
"This ordinary person is precisely the mundane truth.
Sages also do not see this ordinary person."
Again he inquired,
"Since sages do not see ordinary people,
how do they know that ordinary people see mundane truths?"
The imperial edict replied,
"Although sages themselves are without the ordinary,
they can also know that the ordinary exists.
They consider themselves to exist.
Therefore, they flexibly respond to their sentiments and speak of mundane truths."
Wáng Guī 王規, the Sītú 從事中郎, inquired,
I have not yet understood how truth and the mundane can be different.
How can the meaning of mutual identity be obtained?
Decree answers:
What the sage obtains, he sees as without.
What the common person obtains, he sees as having.
Seeing is inherently different.
It does not hinder the mundane from not being outside the true.
Further inquiry:
I have not yet understood, since there is no difference,
how the essence has two meanings.
Should the meaning be separated from the substance,
or should the meaning be identical to the substance?
Decree answers:
Not emerging from each other is called one substance.
The views of the foolish and the wise differ, naturally forming different meanings.
Further inquiry:
Does the common person only see the mundane, or can they also see the true?
Decree answers:
They can only see the mundane; they cannot see the true.
Further inquiry:
Since the substance is mutually identical, how can one not perceive the true?
Decree answers:
If one sees the true, one should not perceive the mundane.
Since perceiving the mundane is deluded, how can one see the true?
Qiān (遷), a monk from Línggēn Temple (靈根寺), asked:
If primarily using "without excess" as the meaning,
this is a name of praise.
If the true is separate from the mundane, it should also be a name of praise.
The imperial edict replied,
"It is precisely this that embodies truth.
One must not speak of praise."
You have already established a beautiful name for the supreme truth.
Therefore, it is praise.
Further questioning:
"If 'none surpassing me' already receives the epithet of praise,
and my essence is thus true,
why is it not praise?"
The imperial edict replied,
"'None surpassing me' is why praise is received.
My essence is true; this also is my truth.
Therefore, it is not praise."
Further questioning:
"'I am without fault.'
Therefore, it is given the epithet of praise.
'I am not false'; why can it not be praise?"
The imperial edict replied,
"'Not false' is the name of the true essence itself.
Just as when someone embodies the meaning, we call it 'understanding the meaning.'
It is precisely sufficient to describe its true essence.
How could it become praise?"
Further questioning:
"This dharma has no one who can surpass it.
How can it immediately be praise?"
The imperial edict replied,
"Since it is said there is 'no surpassing,'
how is it not praise?"
Luó Píng hóu Xiāo Zhènglì consulted, saying:
"I don't know whether conventional truth (sú dì) is a 'becoming' (shēng) phenomenon or not."
The imperial edict replied:
"The substance of conventional truth is precisely a 'becoming' phenomenon."
He further consulted:
"Since the conventional is seen horizontally,
how can there be 'becoming'?"
The imperial edict replied:
"Because horizontal seeing takes it as existent,
therefore there is 'becoming'."
He further consulted:
"Horizontal seeing takes it as existent,
but in reality, there is no Dharma (fǎ).
Since in reality there is no Dharma, what is meant by 'becoming'?"
The imperial edict replied:
"This very 'becoming' phenomenon is called horizontal seeing.
And this very horizontal seeing is called a 'becoming' phenomenon."
He further consulted:
"If it is horizontal seeing, there should be no 'becoming'.
If there must be 'becoming', what is it called horizontal seeing?"
The imperial edict replied:
"Since it is called horizontal seeing,
in reality, there is no 'becoming'.
But horizontal seeing takes it as existent,
and hence this horizontal 'becoming'."
Héngshān hóu Xiāo Gōng consulted, saying:
"I don't know since the highest truth (dì yī yì dì) has a meaning-designation (yì mù),
why does worldly truth (shì dì) alone have no meaning-name (yì míng)?"
The imperial edict replied,
"The world is already shallow and vulgar, and there is no righteousness to be distinguished."
Further question:
"If there is no righteousness to be distinguished,
how can it be called *dì* (諦, truth)?"
The imperial edict replied,
"Because common people clearly see,
therefore the name *dì* is established."
Further question:
"If the common people's seeing something allows it to receive the name *dì*,
then also the common people's seeing something should allow the establishment of the word *yì* (義, righteousness)."
The imperial edict replied,
"Because the common people clearly see,
therefore the name *dì* can be established.
The shallow and vulgar have no righteousness.
How can one forcibly make a word into righteousness?"
Further question:
"Although the shallow and vulgar have no real righteousness,
they are not without the righteousness of the shallow and vulgar.
Since there is this shallow and vulgar,
how can it not receive the name of *yì*?"
The imperial edict replied,
"Precisely because it is shallow and vulgar, there is no righteousness to be distinguished.
If there were righteousness to be distinguished, what would it be called shallow and vulgar?"
The monk Huái (懷) of the Zhōngxīng Sì (中興寺) asked:
"The imperial edict explains,
'The true does not leave the mundane,
the mundane does not leave the true.'
It remains to be seen whether it is truly without form (wú xiàng).
The mundane is with form (yǒu xiàng).
Form and no-form are different.
How can they be of the same substance (tóng tǐ)?
The Imperial decree (lìng zhǐ) replies:
Form and no-form are different in this place.
But all that is seen is "is,"
While what the sage (shèng) sees is "is not."
Using this as the basis for discussion,
It can be considered without distinction.
Further inquiry:
Since it is one Dharma (fǎ),
How can it be seen as two?
Since seeing is in two aspects, how can it be one Dharma?
The Imperial decree replies:
The principle (lǐ) is not two.
According to what things are seen,
Therefore, it can be two.
Further inquiry:
Since seeing is in two aspects,
How can it not contradict?
The Imperial decree replies:
If the Dharma were truly two,
It could contradict.
The Dharma is always not two,
People's seeing is itself two.
Basing the discussion on this,
How could it be contradictory?
Again, I inquire.
People see there are two.
One can say there are two persons.
The principle (lǐ) is already one.
How could there be two?
The decree replies:
Although the principle (lǐ) is not two, it is considered as two in relation to people.
Xiāo Yìng, the fourth son of the Prince of Shǐxīng, inquired:
The meaning of the first principle (dì yī yì dì) is supreme.
Is its virtue (dé) also supreme or not?
The decree replies:
Since its meaning (yì) is supreme,
its virtue (dé) is also supreme.
Again, I inquire.
Directly calling it "first"
already encompasses virtue (dé) and meaning (yì).
Why add the character "meaning" (yì) again, leading to unnecessary complexity?
The decree replies:
Calling it "first" directly still leaves the meaning (yì) unclear.
Seeing it as "first" with meaning (yì) allows for complete perfection.
Again, I inquire.
If adding the character "meaning" (yì) allows for complete perfection,
why not add the character "virtue" (dé) to allow for complete perfection?
The decree replies:
"First" is virtue (dé).
Why wait to add it again?
But adding the character "meaning" (yì) makes virtue (dé) and meaning (yì) both beautiful.
Again, I inquire.
Directly calling it "first" is sufficient to show its beauty.
Partially adding the character "meaning" (yì) seems somewhat limited.
The decree replies:
"First" expresses virtue (dé).
Adding the character "meaning" (yì),
presents both beauties together.
